creator: charles@tuckey.ca
text:
I wanted to post a message to the log4j mailing list but it was denied by the
SPAM filter. I tried various combinations of From: and Reply To: headers. No
luck. I will post an example copy of a bounced message next.

So, I thought I'd email a human. I used log4j-user-help@logging.apache.org to
get help. This help told me a human was at log4j-user-owner@logging.apache.org.
I emailed my plaint to that address. It bounced. I will post this message next.

So, then I thought I'll go the Apache web pages and contact someone there. I
ended up at this page:
http://wiki.apache.org/logging-log4j/Log4JProjectPages
and clicked on this link:
http://logging.apache.org/site/mail.html
and got a 404.

There are three problems here:
1) The SPAM filter on the log4j list is overeager,
2) The help message from log4j is outdated,
3) There are broken links on the log4j web pages.

I really just need problem 1 fixed. But fixing 2 & 3 would save others from
being frustrated as well.

charlie

Created attachment 17192
Reply from spam filter
creator: charles@tuckey.ca
hoju@visi.com
text:
I'm not entirely sure why you are having these problems, but I saw at least 3 or
4 copies of your reply to my email come to the list.  So, it seems that,
although you were getting messages saying that the email had bounced, the emails
actually did go through.

Jake

You are right Jake, I see the messages there now. <Embarrassed grin> When I saw
the bounces I just assumed they weren't getting through.
creator: charles@tuckey.ca
mwomack@apache.org
text:
So, the bounces back to you are still happening?  I can look into why this is,
just want to make sure it is still happening and not some limited time wierd state.

creator: charles@tuckey.ca
text:
Well, I don't post to the list very often. I haven't posted since I had those
problems. But if you like I can post some test messages to help you out.

I don't think it's some weird alternative universe thing because the bounces
happened over the period of about 24 hours.

creator: mwomack@apache.org
text: Can you try it again and forward me the specific bounce email you get back?

Mark, I sent a message about 11 PM MST last night and I didn't receive any
bounce messages. As well, it showed up on the list. The email subject was "Test
- ignore". So, I don't know if you did anything to fix it or not but it seems to
be working now.
creator: charles@tuckey.ca

text:
Created attachment 17251
bounce email from test message sent 051220

Argghh. Gmail put the bounce message in the Spam folder. So, it *did* bounce
but it also put it on the mailing list. Just like in the original problem. I
have attached the complete bounce message in file test_email.
creator: charles@tuckey.ca
mwomack@apache.org
text:
Thanks for the latest, Charles.  I forwarded the information to infrastructure@
to see what knobs I have available to twiddle.  I'll let you know what I find.

creator: mwomack@apache.org
text:
Charles,

According to the experts, the bounce message is not being generated by the ASF
mail server:

The email message you are referring to has not been generated by
an ASF MTA and  I don't see any information in it that any ASF mail
server rejected the message. Instead, the message appears to have been
created by a local MTA on the sender side. 

Could it be generated by a server on your side?

creator: charles@tuckey.ca
text:
Well I am far from an expert as well. But I don't think it's a server at my end
because I'm using gmail and it doesn't make sense that an enroute serve would
bounce it. Besides if it did then the email wouldn't be making it to the mailing
list, which it does. So, I am starting to wonder if it isn't someone on the
mailing list (log4j-users@apache.org) that is generating the bounce message.

Looking through the headers I see these headers pretty soon after the bounce.
So, I suspect it's something on this network that's generating the bounce.

Received: from syscom.be (pluto.syscom.be [193.74.139.106])
 by bpd2mi5no.prod.shawcable.com
 (Sun ONE Messaging Server 6.0 HotFix 1.01 (built Mar 15 2004))
 with ESMTP id <0IRU00E364AGFB00@bpd2mi5no.prod.shawcable.com> for
 charles@tuckey.ca (ORCPT charles@tuckey.ca); Tue,
 20 Dec 2005 23:20:41 -0700 (MST)

X-Spam-Processed: pluto.syscom.be, Wed, 21 Dec 2005 07:20:38 +0100
X-MDAV-Processed: pluto.syscom.be, Wed, 21 Dec 2005 07:20:38 +0100


Further, part of the bounce message body contains these headers:
From      : log4j-user-return-17073-Frans.Morre=os2ug.be@logging.apache.org
To        : Frans.Morre@os2ug.be

So, in particular I am guessing it's this guy's spam filter.

But, why is this message getting bounced back to me (charles@tuckey.ca) instead
of the apache list server? Perhaps your experts know the answer to this? It
doesn't seem like the expected behaviour.

Closing issue since everything seems to be working now.  Marking as INVALID since it didn't pertain to 
log4j itself and don't want it to appear in bug fix reports.
creator: carnold@apache.org
